Graphical abstract Direct evidence for the reaction pathway of methane and hydrogen sulfide reforming (H2SMR) was obtained by in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). The catalytic methane(CH4) and hydrogen sulfide(H2S) reforming (H2SMR) represents a promising approach for producing high-value sulfur-carbon compounds and hydrogen without generating the greenhouse gas of CO2. Despite its significant potential, the mechanistic understanding of interactions between CH4 and H2S remains contentious, posing substantial challenges for catalyst development. In this study, we employed a Mo/Al2O3 catalyst to elucidate synergistic conversion pathways between CH4 and H2S during H2SMR. At 1173 K with a reaction duration of 0.5 h, conversion rates of CH4 and H2S reached 63.7 % and 59.2 %, respectively, accompanied by H2 and CS2 production rates of 688.8 μmol g−1 min−1 and 444.3 μmol g−1 min−1, respectively. Notably, the catalyst exhibited stable performance over 5 h without significant deactivation, in contrast to pure methane cracking reactions where CH4 conversion rapidly declined from 43.6 % to 14.3 %. Through in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) combined with alternating CH4/H2S exposure experiments, we successfully tracked the synergistic conversion pathway on the Mo/Al2O3 catalyst. These investigations revealed that the formation of CH3S intermediates serves as a critical step facilitating CS2 generation. This mechanistic insight not only advances fundamental understanding of H2SMR reaction pathways but also provides a rational foundation for designing optimized catalysts with enhanced stability and extended operational lifetimes. The identification of this intermediate-driven mechanism addresses previous controversies regarding CH4-H2S interactions and offers strategic guidance for developing efficient sulfur-resistant catalytic systems. Keywords Methane Hydrogen sulfide H2SMR Mo/Al2O3 CH3S* intermediates Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen (H2) has emerged as a critical energy vector in the energy transition due to its exceptional energy density (142 MJ/kg) and clean conversion characteristics in fuel cell applications [1]. Currently, steam methane reforming (SMR; Eq. (1)) remains the dominant industrial hydrogen production technology [2,3]. However, its associated water–gas shift (WGS; Eq. (2)) side reaction generates approximately 9 tons of CO2 emissions per ton of H2 produced, significantly undermining carbon reduction objectives. (1) C H 4 + H 2 O ⇋ 3 H 2 + CO Δ H 298 K = 206.1 kJ mo l -1 (2) CO + H 2 O ⇋ H 2 + C O 2 Δ H 298 K = -41.2 kJ mo l - 1 Notably, approximately 40 % of global natural gas reservoirs contain 5–30 % hydrogen sulfide (H2S), which conventional Claus processes convert into low-value sulfur while wasting hydrogen resources [4]. In this context, the methane and hydrogen sulfide reforming (H2SMR; Eq. (3)) demonstrates unique advantages [5–8]: This innovative technology enables direct conversion of high-sulfur natural gas through modification of conventional SMR processes, eliminating both the desulfurization unit which accounts for 15–20 % of capital costs in SMR plants [5] and carbon capture systems that increase energy consumption by 24 % in SMR together with CCUS configurations [6]. (3) C H 4 + 2 H 2 S ⇋ 4 H 2 + C S 2 Δ H 298 K = 232.4kJ mo l -1 Although H2SMR requires elevated operating temperatures (1173–1773 K, 54 % higher than conventional SMR) to prevent carbon deposition [7], comprehensive techno-economic analysis reveals its substantial competitive advantage [5,8]. The elimination of pretreatment and carbon capture units reduces the levelized cost of hydrogen (LCOH) to −1.0/kg, compared to 2.4/kg for conventional SMR [5]. Furthermore, the co-production of carbon disulfide (CS2) – a high-value chemical feedstock with 5–18 times the economic value of elemental sulphur [8] – creates significant economic synergies through applications in synthetic fibers, thin-film materials, and rubber vulcanizing agents [7]. From an environmental perspective, the process achieves a 61.3 % reduction in life cycle carbon intensity compared to conventional SMR, with an additional 41.6 % reduction relative to SMR + CCUS systems [6]. The spontaneous phase-driven separation of gaseous H2 and liquid CS2 product streams significantly simplifies process configuration while enhancing operational efficiency [7,8]. (4) H 2 S ⇋ H 2 + 1/2 S 2 Δ H 298 K = 79.9 kJ mo l -1 (5) C H 4 ⇋ 2 H 2 + C Δ H 298 K = 74.9 kJ mo l -1 Significant mechanistic ambiguities persist in understanding the H2SMR process. The reaction pathway involves intricate dissociation sequences of CH4 and H2S (Eqs. (3)–(4)), with notable discrepancies in identifying the rate-determining step. Megalofonos et al. proposed a triple active-site collaborative mechanism where co-adsorption of CH3, H2S, and sulfur species constitutes the rate-limiting step [9,10]. In contrast, Karan et al. demonstrated through kinetic analyses that CS2 formation predominantly relies on CH4 reactions with thermally decomposed sulfur species, identifying H2S dissociation as the kinetic bottleneck [11]. To reconcile these divergent interpretations, Li et al. developed a full-scale kinetic model encompassing 85 species and 515 elementary reactions [12]. Their simulations revealed CH4 reactivity's strong dependence on free sulfur atom concentration, with CH3 radical interactions with SH/H radicals governing reaction progression. Further insights from Wang's team using isotopic tracing confirmed that dynamically stabilized sulfur dimers (S-S*) on catalyst surfaces mediate initial CH bond cleavage in CH4 [13,14]. However, under quasi-equilibrium conditions, the rate control may shift to irreversible CS bond formation. These conflicting findings underscore critical gaps in characterizing transient intermediates during H2SMR, which significantly hinders the rational design of sulfur-tolerant catalysts. Conventional nickel-based SMR catalysts (e.g., Ni/Al2O3, Ni/SiO2) demonstrate limited applicability in H2S-containing systems due to severe sulfur poisoning issues [15–17]. In contrast, molybdenum-based materials exhibit distinct advantages under sulfiding conditions. Exposure to H2S induces in-situ sulfidation of Mo species, forming layered MoS2 structures.[18,19] The coordinatively unsaturated Mo-S edge sites in these structures not only efficiently cleave H2S molecules but also facilitate CH4 adsorption and dissociation through sulfur vacancy mediation. Critical investigations reveal that the catalytic performance of MoS2 is profoundly influenced by the interfacial microenvironment of the support material [20]. Specifically, the Lewis acid sites (Al3+) and Brønsted acid hydroxyl groups (AlOH) on γ-Al2O3 surfaces synergistically enhance MoS2 dispersion and modulate electronic density at active edge sites through strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) [21–23]. Notably, the interlayer stacking defects in MoS2 architectures serve as dynamic reservoirs for sulfur dimers (SS*). This structural characteristic shows remarkable alignment with the rate-determining step precursor mechanism proposed by Wang et al., thereby establishing an exemplary model system for investigating transient intermediate species behavior during catalytic processes [13,14]. The unique combination of structural adaptability and electronic tunability positions MoS2-based catalysts as promising candidates for sulfur-tolerant methane reforming applications. In this study, Mo/Al2O3 was employed as a model catalyst to investigate the surface reaction pathways between CH4 and H2S through integrated in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) analysis and alternating gas exposure experiments. By identifying critical reaction intermediates and monitoring their dynamic evolution patterns, we elucidate the fundamental mechanisms governing CS bond formation. These mechanistic insights establish a theoretical foundation for designing sulfur-tolerant, highly active catalysts tailored for H2SMR applications. 2 Experimental 2.1 Experimental methods A Mo/Al2O3 catalyst with a loading of 20 wt% was synthesized by a one-step primary wet impregnation method [24]. A certain amount of ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, Aladdin, ≥99.9 %) was dissolved in ultrapure water to prepare a 20 mL precursor solution. The solution was then slowly dropped into 12.268 g activated alumina (γ-Al2O3, Aladdin, ≥99.99 %) and stirred continuously for 10 min to mix well. The Mo/Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by aging at room temperature for 24 h, drying at 393 K for 12 h, and calcining at 820 K for 4 h in an air atmosphere. Grinding and pressing the synthesized catalyst into tablets, passing through a 50–70 mesh sieve. Thermocatalytic reactions were measured in a quartz reactor at atmospheric pressure. The product analysis was conducted by Huifen GCS-90 gas chromatograph, equipped with packed columns (TDX-01, 3 × 1 m; GDX-502, 3 × 4.5 m; GDX-301, 3 × 2 m), a capillary column (HF-Sulfur, 60 m × 0.53 mm × 10 um), a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), a flame ionization detector (FID), and a flame photometric detector (FPD). The micro morphology of catalyst was tested by scanning electron microscope (SEM) using ZEISS Gemini 300, and transmission electron microscope (TEM) using FEI TAlOS F200S. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas and pore sizes were measured on an equipment (Micromeritics ASAP 2460) employing N2 adsorption/desorption. Before measuring, the catalysts were outgassed at 573 K for 3 h under vacuum. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a PANalytical X’Pert PRO powder diffraction system using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15418, 40 kV/40 mA) in the scattering angle (2θ) range of 10–70°. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were made in the near-surface element states of catalyst using Thermo Scientific K-Alpha system with an Al-Ka X-ray source (1486.6 eV). The standard C 1s peak of graphite at 284.8 eV was used to calibrate all energies of the XPS spectra. In-situ DRIFTS was carried out on a Bruker infrared spectrometer (Tensor II) equipped with a liquid nitrogen cooled mercury−cadmium−telluride (MCT) detector in a three-window diffuse-reflectance cell (Harrick) with a nonmodified dome cover. Two IR measurement windows were made of ZnSe. The resolution was 4 cm−1. The IR scanning range was 4000−600 cm−1 with averaging over 100 scans. The gas composition and flow rate were consistent with the catalytic tests. The background spectra were obtained by purged the pretreated catalysts at 616 K in pure Ar gas for 30 min. 2.2 Thermal catalytic H2SMR reactions The sulfidation of the Mo/Al2O3 catalyst was performed following a method analogous to established protocols, with modifications to gas-phase composition and thermal treatment parameters [24]. Place 100 mg of catalyst in a quartz tube, and pass through argon to remove the air. 0.02 bar H2S in Ar (1 bar total) was injected at 50 mL min−1 for 30 min, then the reactor was heated from room temperature to 773 K at 10 K min−1 and kept for 1 h, then cooled to room temperature, and the introduction of hydrogen sulfide was stopped. After blowing argon again for 30 min to purge the residual gas, it was kept at room temperature for 30 min at 100 mL min−1 with a pressure ratio of 0.0067 bar CH4 and 0.0133 H2S in Ar (1 bar total). The reactor was heated from room temperature to 1173 K at 10 K min−1, and then gas components were detected by gas chromatography (GCS-90). The catalyst treated with hydrogen sulfide under 773 K is marked as sulfurized-Mo/Al2O3, while the catalyst after reaction under 1173 K is marked as used-Mo/Al2O3. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization Considering the dual role of H2S as both reactant and sulfiding agent in the H2SMR system, comprehensive characterization of the Mo/Al2O3 catalyst — including its structural, morphological, and surface chemical properties — was exclusively performed on the sulfided material to authentically represent the operando state under H2S-containing reaction environments. The structural evolution of sulfided Mo/Al2O3 catalysts was investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis (Fig. S1). The catalyst exhibited characteristic diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS 80-0956) at 37°, 43°-48°, and 67°, demonstrating the structural stability of the alumina support. Additionally, the catalyst showed significantly diffraction intensities corresponding to the (002), (100), (103), and (110) crystal planes of MoS2 (JCPDS 75–1539) at 14°, 33°, 40°, and 58°, respectively [24]. Fig. S2 illustrates the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of sulfurized-Mo/Al2O3, which exhibit a Type IV isotherm with an H3-type hysteresis loop, characteristic of slit-shaped mesopores formed by the aggregation of plate-like particles. The sharp increase in adsorption at high relative pressures (p/p0 > 0.8) confirms the presence of mesoporous structures with capillary condensation. Table S1 presents the specific surface area of 144.9 m2 g−1 and pore size data, with an average pore volume of 0.7 cm3 g−1 and pore size of 19.6 nm, consistent with the open porous network inferred from the hysteresis behavior. Comprehensive SEM and TEM characterization was performed to investigate the morphological evolution of Mo/Al2O3 catalysts after sulfidation. As shown in Fig. 1 a–c, the sulfidized catalysts exhibit distinct flake-like nanostructures with well-defined layered morphology formed through in-situ transformation of Mo species. The observed lattice fringe spacing of 0.63 nm in Fig. 1c corresponds to the (002) crystallographic plane of hexagonal MoS2, confirming successful sulfidation [25–27]. Elemental mapping (Fig. 1d–h) reveals homogeneous spatial distribution of Al, O, Mo, and S elements across the support surface, indicative of uniform MoS2 overlayer formation on Al2O3. This structural uniformity originates from the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) between MoO3 precursors and Lewis acid sites (Al3+) on γ-Al2O3, which effectively anchors the precursor species, prevents particle agglomeration, and ultimately promotes the formation of small-sized MoS2 crystallites with abundant exposed edge sites [23]. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) analysis was conducted to probe metal-support interactions in Mo/Al2O3, with commercial MoS2 and γ-Al2O3 as references (Fig. S3). The bare γ-Al2O3 support exhibited no reduction peaks, demonstrating exceptional thermal stability within the tested temperature range. Commercial MoS2 showed a broad reduction feature between 1073–1273 K corresponding to bulk sulfide reduction [28,29]. In contrast, the Mo/Al2O3 catalyst displayed two distinct reduction signals: 1) an intense low-temperature peak at 453 K attributed to the removal of edge/interfacial sulfur species from highly dispersed MoS2 nanostructures, and 2) a weakened high-temperature peak at 1162 K associated with partial reduction of MoS2 [30,31]. Notably, this high-temperature peak exhibited both intensity attenuation and low-temperature shift compared to pure MoS2, suggesting electronic modification of MoS2 through electron transfer from Al3+ Lewis acid sites [22]. This electron-deficient state of Mo could weaken MoS bonding strength while enhancing CH bond activation capability [23]. 3.2 Thermal catalytic H2SMR reactions Although acidic natural gas normally contains 5–30 % H2S, the rapid deactivation caused by carbon/sulfur deposition under high CH4/H2S ratio occurred (Fig. S4). This leads to a critical bottleneck limiting mechanistic studies of H2SMR, therefore, we evaluated catalyst performance in controlled environments containing low concentrations of CH4 and H2S (total concentration 2 %). Firstly, we systematically investigated the synergistic conversion mechanisms by examining various reaction parameters including support materials, catalyst composition, Mo loading amount, reaction temperature, gas flow rate, and CH4/H2S molar ratio (Figs. S5–S11). As demonstrated in Fig. S5, hydrogen production exhibited significant enhancement at elevated temperatures (>1173 K), with optimal activity observed within the 1173–1273 K range over different supports. Comparative analysis of transition metal catalysts revealed molybdenum-based systems showed superior synergistic conversion efficiency compared to other metals (Fig. S6). Notably, γ-Al2O3-supported catalysts demonstrated exceptional hydrogen production performance (681.2 μmol g−1 min−1), outperforming other oxide supports (218–291 μmol g−1 min−1) as shown in Fig. S7, which might be due to the synergistic interactions between Lewis acid sites (Al3+) and Brønsted acidic hydroxyl groups (Al-OH) [21–23]. The catalytic performance displayed a parabolic relationship with Mo loading on γ-Al2O3, peaking at 10 wt% and showed slightly decrease with increase the amount of Mo (Fig. S8). More importantly, these Mo loaded γ-Al2O3 catalysts showed a stable formation of H2 and CS2 products during 5-hour reaction (Fig. S9), which made them as a well candidate for the mechanism study. Increasing total gas flow rate from 20 to 200 mL min−1 reduced CH4 and H2S conversions by 33.1 % and 23.2 % respectively, attributable to decreased residence time (Fig. S10). Besides, the CH4/H2S molar ratio also showed significant effect on CH4 and H2S conversion and products formation (Fig. S11), whereas CH4 and H2S at 1:2 showed the best balanced conversion of CH4 and H2S. Through this multidimensional structure–activity relationship study, we established optimized reaction conditions: reaction temperature of 1173 K, with 0.0067 bar CH4 and 0.0133 bar H2S in Ar (1 bar total), and total flow rate of 100 mL min−1, by employing a 20 % Mo/Al2O3 catalyst. This configuration achieved balanced catalytic activity and CH4 utilization efficiency while maintaining stable operation under sulfiding conditions. The selected parameters effectively minimized thermal cracking side reactions. As shown in Figs. 2 a and S9, the catalyst demonstrated remarkable stability during 5 h H2SMR operation, achieving initial H2 and CS2 production rates of 688.8 and 444.3 μmol g−1 min−1 respectively at 0.5 h, with corresponding CH4 and H2S conversions of 63.7 % and 59.2 %. These metrics surpass previously reported H2SMR catalysts in both activity and stability (Table S2). Comparative analysis of H2SMR with individual H2S and CH4 cracking reactions revealed distinct activation behaviors. While H2S cracking maintained stable sulfur tolerance over 5 h, CH4 cracking exhibited significant deactivation (43.6 % to 14.3 % conversion decrease), likely due to carbon deposition. Notably, H2 production in H2SMR (681.2 μmol g−1 min−1) substantially exceeded the sum of individual cracking reactions (317.5 μmol g−1 min−1 total), with concurrent enhancements in CH4 and H2S conversions (38.5 % and 16.7 % increases at 2.5 h respectively). Activation rates showed similar improvements: CH4 activation increased from 59.3 to 187.9 μmol g−1 min−1, while H2S activation rose from 253.5 to 346.8 μmol g−1 min−1 (Figs. 2b, S12). The temporal stability of CH4 conversion suggests effective mitigation of carbon-induced deactivation through H2S co-feeding. These collective findings establish H2SMR as a fundamentally distinct process from simple cracking mechanisms. To Study the mechanism of the synergistic conversion phenomenon, we analyzed the phase change after reaction of H2SMR. Additional structural changes were observed through the emergence of Al2(SO4)3 diffraction signals at 18° in spent catalysts (Fig. S1), attributable to surface sulfation of γ-Al2O3 through H2S interaction at elevated temperatures. While excessive MoS2 stacking could theoretically reduce edge-active sites and Al2(SO4)3 formation might compromise structural integrity through thermal decomposition, these structural modifications showed a slight impact on catalytic performance (Figs. S8 and S9). Therefore, it is possible that the maintained activity throughout the reaction period implies that neither MoS2 stacking nor support sulfation significantly affects the catalytically active sites. This remarkable stability suggests that the catalytic functionality primarily depends on a limited number of highly active surface sites rather than bulk structural characteristics. The apparent decoupling between structural evolution and catalytic performance highlights the critical need for advanced surface characterizations to identify these active sites. A comparative XPS investigation was conducted on sulfurized Mo/Al2O3 catalysts and their post-reaction counterparts to elucidate the chemical environments of Mo, S, Al, and O, with particular emphasis on the evolution of molybdenum species during catalytic operation. Fig. 3 a presents the experimental and deconvoluted XPS spectra of Mo 3d and S 2 s orbitals in the 224–240 eV range. The spectral fitting reveals four distinct components: two pairs of doublets at 229.2/232.5 eV corresponding to MoS2, 230.1/233.6 eV assigned to MoOxSy species, and 231.9/235.2 eV characteristic of MoO3. Quantitative analysis based on peak area ratios demonstrates that the sulfurized-Mo/Al2O3 catalyst exhibits a sulfurization degree (combined proportion of MoS2 and MoOxSy) of 86.3 %, with MoS2 constituting 81.6 % of total molybdenum species. This indicates successful conversion of over 80 % molybdenum oxide precursors into catalytically active MoS2 through sulfurization treatment. The lower binding energy contribution at 226.6 eV corresponds to the S 2s orbital, consistent with established literature values. The S 2p spectral evolution shown in Fig. 3b reveals distinct sulfate species (SO4 2−) at 169.1 eV and 170.1 eV [32–34]. Notably, the post-reaction catalyst exhibits a 0.8 eV positive binding energy shift in sulfate peaks compared to the fresh sulfurized catalyst (168.5 eV vs. 169.3 eV), suggesting electronic environment modifications during catalytic operation. Fig. 3c displays the Al 2p transitions with two overlapping bands at 74.5 eV and 75.3 eV, corresponding to tetrahedrally and octahedrally coordinated aluminum atoms in the Al2O3 support matrix, respectively [35]. In Fig. 3d, the peaks at 530.5 eV, 531.5 eV, and 532.9 eV are associated with lattice oxygen (O2–, Olat), surface-absorbed water (Osurf), and surface hydroxyl groups (–OH, Oads), respectively [36]. The elemental composition analysis conducted by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Table S3) revealed notable discrepancies between experimental measurements and theoretical predictions for the 20 %Mo/Al2O3 material. The molybdenum content was determined to be 13.0 wt%, exceeding the theoretical value of 12.0 wt%, while the sulfur content measured 7.4 wt%, slightly below the predicted 8.0 wt%. This resulted in an experimental S/Mo molar ratio of 0.57, representing a 14.9 % reduction from the theoretical ratio of 0.67. The sulfur deficit may be attributed to sulfur volatilization or partial oxidation during the synthesis process, whereas the elevated molybdenum content could originate from localized enrichment of MoS2 species on the catalyst support surface. Despite a marked reduction in specific surface area during the reaction (Table S1), the Mo/Al2O3 catalyst demonstrated stable catalytic activity. This stability was further validated through systematic evaluation of low Mo-loading catalysts (Fig. S9). These findings imply that the genuine active sites for CH4 and H2S coupling are not surface-anchored metal cation-sulfur(oxygen) anion pairs, but rather surface species that play a dominant catalytic role. 3.3 In-situ DRIFTS We performed an in-situ DRIFTS experiment on CH4 and H2S reforming at 1173 K, as illustrated in Fig. 4 and Fig. S13. Initially, a band attributed to thiol at 2600 cm−1 was observed, indicating the presence of H2S [37–40]. Concurrently, bands corresponding to CS and gaseous CH4 at 2100 cm−1 and 1300 cm−1, respectively, were detected, signifying CH4 cracking and CS2 production [37,41–43]. Notably, signals of various intermediate species formed during the CH4 and H2S reaction were identified in the range of 1100 cm−1 to 1500 cm−1. Among these, the bands at 1337 cm−1 and 1228 cm−1 were ascribed to CH3S* and CH2S*, with their intensities increasing over time [39,41,44]. It is significant that these results diverge markedly from the reported H2SMR reaction mechanism. The in-situ DRIFTS findings suggest that CS2 is unlikely to form directly from the combination of adsorbed S* and C* on the catalyst surface. Instead, intermediate species such as CH3S* and CH2S* were detected, which are formed from the reaction of adsorbed CH3*, S*, and SH*. These carbon–sulfur intermediates, after losing all hydrogen atoms, likely combine with an additional sulfur atom to eventually form CS2. 3.4 Alternating exposure experiment We conducted an alternating exposure experiment of CH4 and H2S coupled with in-situ DRIFTS techniques (Fig. 5 and Table S4), to elucidate the key intermediate species on the catalyst surface and their reaction mechanisms. Fig. 5a–d present the catalytic activity of the experimental group with CH4 first introduced into the reactor (based on the fixed-bed reactor-GC coupled system). The initial introduction of CH4 resulted in significant H2 production (963.6 μmol g−1 min−1), which markedly decreased over the course of the alternating reaction (Fig. 5a). This decline is attributed to carbon deposition from CH4 cracking, which covers the active sites on the Mo/Al2O3 catalyst, thereby reducing the conversion rate (Fig. 5d). In contrast, when H2S was substituted for CH4, the hydrogen production rate from H2S decomposition remained remarkably stable at 245.5 μmol g−1 min−1, while the H2S conversion rate showed no significant variation (Fig. 5c). This observation suggests that the active sites involved in CH4 and H2S activation are likely mutually independent − a conclusion corroborated by temperature-programmed in-situ DRIFTS experiments (Fig. S14). Specifically, the adsorption peak intensities for both CH4 and H2S exhibited continuous enhancement with increasing temperature (323–573 K), and no competitive adsorption was observed between the two reactants. Notably, CS2 was detected upon the initial replacement of CH4 with H2S (Fig. 5b), with its production significantly increasing at 1.5 h compared to 0.5 h after the first introduction of H2S (Fig. 5c). This trend of initial increase followed by a decrease over time (in both CH4 and H2S atmospheres) suggests that while the CH4 conversion rate significantly declined between 0–1 h, the concentration of key intermediate species promoting CS2 formation was still limited and had not reached equilibrium, resulting in increased CS2 production before 2 h. Once the concentration of key intermediates balanced, constrained by the declining CH4 conversion rate, CS2 production also decreased. The in-situ DRIFTS during the alternating exposure (based on the in-situ DRIFTS reaction cell) of CH4 and H2S revealed that upon the initial introduction of CH4, adsorbed state bands corresponding to SH*, CH4*, CS2*, CH3S*, and CH2S* intermediate species were detected on the catalyst surface, even before H2S was introduced (Fig. 5e). When CH4 was replaced with H2S, the CH4* bands disappeared, and the signal intensities of CS2*, CH3S*, and CH2S* bands significantly reduced. These band signals intensified again when H2S was replaced by CH4. These results demonstrate that in a CH4 atmosphere alone, CH4 can be activated by the small amount of sulfur species present on the Mo/Al2O3 surface, forming intermediates such as CH3*, CH3S*, CH2S*, and CS2*. These small amounts of sulfur species not only do not interfere with CH4 activation but also facilitate a high CH4 conversion rate at 0.5 h (94.5 %). However, the absence of CH3* when replacing CH4 with H2S halts the substantial formation of CH3S*, a key intermediate in the combination of CH4 and H2S, leading to a significant reduction in the signal intensities of CH2S* and CS2* bands, intermediates derived from the dehydrogenation of CH3S*. Reintroduction of CH4 replenishes CH3*, enhancing the signal bands of these intermediates once again. To further verify the key intermediate species in the H2SMR reaction, we conducted a control experiment involving the alternating exposure of CH4 and H2S, with H2S introduced into the reactor first (Fig. 6 a–e, Table S5). In this experimental group, the H2S conversion rate and H2 yield were very similar to those observed when CH4 was introduced first (Fig. 6a and e). However, when H2S was replaced with CH4, the CH4 conversion rate was significantly lower compared to the experimental group where CH4 was introduced first (Fig. 6d). This is attributed to the large amount of sulfur species generated by the thermal cracking of H2S, which covered the active sites on the catalyst surface responsible for CH4 activation. This suggests that the CH3* radicals generated when CH4 is introduced first can effectively mitigate the activity reduction caused by sulfur deposition on the catalyst surface. In contrast to the experimental group where CH4 was introduced first, no CS2 formation was detected after completing the first cycle of alternating exposure of H2S and CH4. CS2 was only detected after H2S was reintroduced. This indicates that CS2 formation occurs only when CH4 first reacts on the catalyst surface and generates related intermediate species, which then react with subsequently added H2S. The in-situ infrared spectra of the experimental group where H2S was introduced first confirm this viewpoint. When H2S was introduced first, no CH4*, CH3S*, or CH2S* bands were observed. These bands became noticeable only after CH4 was introduced and then weakened when CH4 was replaced with H2S. The results of the alternating exposure experiments of CH4 and H2S, along with their control group, indicate that CH3S* is the key intermediate promoting the combination of CH4 and H2S to form CS2. The formation of this intermediate depends on a small amount of S* active sites on the catalyst surface. As a key intermediate, CH3S* can gradually dehydrogenate to eventually form CS2, thus establishing a dynamic consumption process of carbon and sulfur species on the catalyst surface. This well explains the synergistic conversion of methane and hydrogen sulfide (Fig. 2). Moreover, this process effectively avoids catalyst deactivation due to carbon and sulfur deposition, enhancing the catalyst's stability and lifespan. By comparing the effects of different CH4:H2S ratios on the catalyst structure and sulfur vacancies (Fig. S15), and the resulting catalytic performance variations (Fig. S11), it was found that although changes in the CH4:H2S ratio alter the amount of the 2H-MoS2 phase and the S:Mo ratio in the MoS2Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. S15a and b), these changes do not show a clear correlation with catalytic performance. This suggests that the concentration of the 2H-MoS2 phase and sulfur vacancies on the catalyst surface are not the key factors determining catalytic activity. Experimental observations revealed optimal synergistic conversion when the CH4:H2S ratio was maintained at the stoichiometric value of 1:2 (Fig. S11), with both reactants achieving conversion rates approaching 60 %. This phenomenon further corroborates the dynamic consumption of surface species on the catalyst during the reaction process. Deviation from this optimal ratio through excess CH4 or H2S was found to disrupt the critical carbon–sulfur (C-S) equilibrium, thereby diminishing the mutual enhancement effect between methane and hydrogen sulfide. Such imbalance may ultimately lead to catalyst deactivation through dual mechanisms of carbon deposition and sulfur accumulation. This finding aligns with the recent report by Yong W. et al. [13,14] which, through theoretical calculations and indirect characterization methods, proposed that catalytic activity is not directly associated with traditional surface structures such as metal–sulfur or metal–oxygen pairs, but rather with sulfur dimers dynamically stabilized on the catalyst surface, which function as active sites. However, this study goes a step further by directly revealing that the CH3S* intermediate, promoted by a small amount of sulfur species (S*) on the catalyst surface, plays a crucial role in the combination of CH4 and H2S. This conclusion was drawn through alternating exposure experiments combined with in-situ DRIFTS techniques. The presence of CH2S* indicates that this intermediate undergoes gradual dehydrogenation, ultimately forming CS2. Kinetic analysis of the four elementary steps (Eqs. S1–S4) reveals that the reaction proceeds through sequential CH bond activation and sulfur-mediated dehydrogenation. The rate-determining step corresponds to the surface reaction between CH3* and SH* to form CH3S* (Eq. S3), as supported by the dynamic correlation between CH3*/SH* coverages and CS2 formation rate (Fig. S13). Rapid equilibration of H2S dissociation (Eq. S1) and CH4 dissociation (Eq. S2) ensures efficient replenishment of CH3* and S* intermediates, while the exergonic CS2 desorption (Eq. S4) drives the reaction equilibrium forward. This concerted mechanism effectively limits the lifetime of reactive carbonaceous intermediates on the catalyst surface, thereby suppressing carbon deposition and sulfur poisoning while maintaining sustained H2 production over 5-hour operation. Based on the aforementioned conclusions, we propose the following reaction mechanism for methane and hydrogen sulfide catalytic reforming: The rate-determining step is the surface reaction between CH3* and SH* (Eq. S3), not the initial CH bond cleavage in CH4. After the first CH bond in CH4 is cleaved (generating adsorbed CH3*), a series of rapid transformations occur on the catalyst surface, as depicted in steps ①–⑦ (Fig. S16). Unlike conventional CH4/H2S cracking, the equilibrium conversion in H2SMR is constrained by competing side reactions (e.g., H2S decomposition, CH4 cracking) and the thermal stability of CS2 at elevated temperatures. Thermodynamic calculations under ideal conditions predict CH4 conversion exceeding 95 % at 1173 K. However, experimental measurements revealed lower conversions of 63.7 % for CH4 and 59.2 % for H2S (Fig. 2b), indicating kinetic limitations arising from surface intermediates and catalyst deactivation rather than thermodynamic constraints. Mechanistic analysis demonstrates that CH3S acts as the pivotal intermediate during H2SMR, undergoing sequential reactions with atomic S and SH* species through stepwise dehydrogenation to ultimately form CS2. This CH3S-mediated pathway facilitates CH/SH bond cleavage while mitigating carbon/sulfur deposition, thereby enhancing practical performance toward the thermodynamic threshold. Additionally, the rapid consumption of CH3* and S* shifts the reaction equilibrium forward, mutually promoting the conversion of CH4 and H2S. Compared to the cracking reactions of individual gases, this process simultaneously increases the conversion rates of the reactants and the yield of hydrogen, consistent with the experimental results shown in Fig. 3. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, this study provides a comprehensive investigation into the catalytic H2SMR over Mo/Al2O3 catalysts, revealing the intrinsic synergistic mechanism between CH4 and H2S and the pivotal role of key intermediate species. Comparative analysis of pure CH4 cracking, pure H2S cracking, and H2SMR demonstrated distinct performance characteristics. The H2SMR system maintained stable CH4 and H2S conversion rates of approximately 63 % and 58 % respectively over 5 h, while pure CH4 cracking exhibited a rapid decline from 43.6 % to 14.3 % conversion, and pure H2S decomposition showed fluctuating conversions around 42 %. Through in-situ DRIFTS, we established that CS2 formation does not originate from direct combination of surface-adsorbed sulfur and carbon species, but rather evolves through reactions involving adsorbed CH3*, S, and SH species forming intermediate CH3S and CH2S species. Pre-exposure to CH4 generated stable CH3S* and CH2S* species that reduced sulfur coverage and sustained high CS2 production activity, whereas H2S pre-exposure led to active site blocking by sulfur species, inhibiting CH4 conversion and CS2 generation. Further investigations revealed that catalytic performance correlates not with static structural parameters like 2H-phase content or S:Mo ratios in MoS2/Al2O3, but rather with dynamic CH3S* intermediate pathways. The mechanism driving CH4-H2S coupling into CS2 involves dehydrogenation of dynamically stabilized CH3S species followed by sulfur atom incorporation. This dynamic pathway effectively prevents carbon deposition and sulfur accumulation, significantly enhancing catalyst stability. Our findings provide new insights for designing efficient H2SMR catalysts with dual resistance to coking and sulfur poisoning, highlighting the importance of regulating dynamic surface intermediate processes rather than conventional structural optimization approaches. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic methane(CH4) and hydrogen sulfide(H2S) reforming (H2SMR) represents a promising approach for producing high-value sulfur-carbon compounds and hydrogen without generating the greenhouse gas of CO2. Despite its significant potential, the mechanistic understanding of interactions between CH4 and H2S remains contentious, posing substantial challenges for catalyst development. In this study, we employed a Mo/Al2O3 catalyst to elucidate synergistic conversion pathways between CH4 and H2S during H2SMR. At 1173 K with a reaction duration of 0.5 h, conversion rates of CH4 and H2S reached 63.7 % and 59.2 %, respectively, accompanied by H2 and CS2 production rates of 688.8 μmol g−1 min−1 and 444.3 μmol g−1 min−1, respectively. Notably, the catalyst exhibited stable performance over 5 h without significant deactivation, in contrast to pure methane cracking reactions where CH4 conversion rapidly declined from 43.6 % to 14.3 %. Through in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) combined with alternating CH4/H2S exposure experiments, we successfully tracked the synergistic conversion pathway on the Mo/Al2O3 catalyst. These investigations revealed that the formation of CH3S intermediates serves as a critical step facilitating CS2 generation. This mechanistic insight not only advances fundamental understanding of H2SMR reaction pathways but also provides a rational foundation for designing optimized catalysts with enhanced stability and extended operational lifetimes. The identification of this intermediate-driven mechanism addresses previous controversies regarding CH4-H2S interactions and offers strategic guidance for developing efficient sulfur-resistant catalytic systems.
